title: Provide a structured suggestion on `where`-clause restriction on borrow with no named lifetime

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: A-suggestion-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: suggestions generated by the compiler applied by cargo fix

labels.name: D-papercut
labels.description: Diagnostic error that needs small tweaks

labels.name: D-verbose
labels.description: Too much output caused by a single piece of incorrect code

body:
[Given](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=cd678f2897ad415ddfe21b0ef60dd812):

```rust
fn bar<R>(r: &R) where &R: std::io::Read {
    let _ = std::io::Read::read_exact(&mut r, &mut []);
}
```

The compiler outputs

```
error[E0637]: `&` without an explicit lifetime name cannot be used here
 --> src/lib.rs:1:24
  |
1 | fn bar<R>(r: &R) where &R: std::io::Read {
  |                        ^ explicit lifetime name needed here

error[E0310]: the parameter type `R` may not live long enough
 --> src/lib.rs:1:28
  |
1 | fn bar<R>(r: &R) where &R: std::io::Read {
  |        -                   ^^^^^^^^^^^^^ ...so that the reference type `&'static R` does not outlive the data it points at
  |        |
  |        help: consider adding an explicit lifetime bound...: `R: 'static`
```

I believe missing lifetimes in `where` clauses should [provide a structured suggestion in the same way that we do when we find a return borrowed type without a lifetime](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=1281c93a1fc7634da60ea5bc2837f257):

```
error[E0106]: missing lifetime specifier
 --> src/lib.rs:1:28
  |
1 | fn bar<R>(r: &R, t: &R) -> &R {
  |              --     --     ^ expected named lifetime parameter
  |
  = help: this function's return type contains a borrowed value, but the signature does not say whether it is borrowed from `r` or `t`
help: consider introducing a named lifetime parameter
  |
1 | fn bar<'a, R>(r: &'a R, t: &'a R) -> &'a R {
  |        ^^^       ^^^^^     ^^^^^     ^^^
```

The second now unnecessary error should also be silenced:

```
error[E0637]: `&` without an explicit lifetime name cannot be used here
 --> src/lib.rs:1:24
  |
1 | fn bar<R>(r: &R) where &R: std::io::Read {
  |                        ^ explicit lifetime name needed here
  |
help: `where`-clause restrictions on borrowed types require an explicit lifetime
  |
1 | fn bar<'a, R>(r: &'a R) where &'a R: std::io::Read {
  |        ^^^       ^^^^^        ^^^^^
```
